nodes.bodyText: See below comment. As long as len never exceeds 1028 I think this is fine.

Okay. I think I see the difference here. The Adler flavor is using a special pass-through stream that handles checksum computation. That's not a built-in option for SHA-256 so we need to do a manual handoff between streams.
The local byte array buffer is only being used to cache the handoff. The outputStream has an internal byte array that will resize itself as necessary.
I think this will work fine.
(❓ ) Do we need to handle the case where len is zero?
Found a different utility that simplifies this
( ❓ ) The Adler32 version is faster. Do we want to replace all instances of it with the Sha256 version or let callers decide which one they want?
I'm in favor of making it configurable with Adler32 being the default.

( ❓ ) Can we validate these using a separate tool just to be sure? For example, I'm not getting consistent results leveraging Python when I expect I should.
$ python -c "import hashlib; m = hashlib.sha256(); m.update('Hello World'); print(m.hexdigest());"
a591a6d40bf420404a011733cfb7b190d62c65bf0bcda32b57b277d9ad9f146e

See https://docs.python.org/3/library/hashlib.html for details.
the tests are using an object stream for simplicity, so it's not a 1:1 encoding of the string 'Hello World'
and the consumer uses it similarly https://github.com/codice/ddf/blob/master/catalog/plugin/catalog-plugin-checksum/src/main/java/org/codice/ddf/catalog/content/plugin/checksum/Checksum.java#L72

I agree that we should have tests with object streams since that's how it's used in prod. But having the testString right next to the checksumCompareHash is misleading since we're not doing a 1:1 mapping there but instead are using an object stream.
( ❓ ) For all the tests, can we in-line the hash within the assertThat statement?
I think that would help without redundant tests or comments.
